content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a rational player, I would consider this as a repeated game of mixed strategies. In a pure strategy Nash equilibrium, both players would choose R or B consistently, but that results in a lower payoff for both (20$ each round). Instead, I would use a mixed strategy, which is a probability distribution over the available choices.

In this case, since the rewards are not symmetric (getting 45$ vs getting 40$), we cannot assume a 50-50 chance of picking R or B. To maximize my expected payoff, I would pick R more often if the anonymous player tends to choose R and less often if they tend to choose B.

However, since I don't know the strategy of my opponent, I can only make an educated guess. Given that there is a positive reward for both choices (R brings a higher reward but a zero payoff when the opponent chooses B), I would lean slightly towards choosing R more often (let's say 60% of the time) and append my choice as {R}. But remember, the actual optimal strategy depends on the unknown strategy of my opponent. This is just a reasonable guess based on the information provided.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In the next round, since I know my opponent chose R in the previous round and we both received a reward of 45$, it would be reasonable to assume that my opponent will also choose R again. However, as a rational player, I should not expect my opponent to follow the same strategy every time. They might change their strategy based on past observations or random factors.

Since I don't have enough information about my opponent's strategy, I would stick with my initial mixed strategy of choosing R 60% of the time and B 40% of the time in the next round. This way, if my opponent has indeed changed their strategy to B, there is still a chance that I will choose R and receive 40$.

In conclusion, I would choose R again as {R}. But keep in mind that this decision is based on assuming a rational opponent who might not follow the same strategy every time.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this case, I made a mistake by choosing B when my opponent chose R. To maximize my expected payoff in the future, I should adjust my strategy based on this observation. Since I got a higher reward (40$) for picking B when my opponent chose R, it would make sense to increase the probability of choosing B when I expect my opponent to choose R.

However, as a rational player, I cannot be sure that my opponent will always pick R in future rounds. They might change their strategy based on past observations or random factors. So I would stick with a mixed strategy but adjust it slightly by increasing the probability of choosing B when facing an opponent who chose R.

In conclusion, I would choose B again as {B}. But keep in mind that this decision is based on assuming a rational opponent who might not follow the same strategy every time.
